  <div id="post-heading">
    <h3>Facebook Forces <i>NYT</i> to Quietly Delete Unflattering Reference to Sheryl Sandberg</h3>
    <div class="dateline">by <a href="https://lawandcrime.com/author/colin-kalmbacher/" title="Posts by Colin Kalmbacher" rel="author">Colin Kalmbacher</a> | 4:42 pm, March 20th, 2018</div>
  </div> <!-- end post-heading -->
  
  <main>
    <article>
            
        <div id="post-wrap">

          <div id="post-social">
              <div id="share-cont">
    <div id="share">

          <div id="post-body">
            <p><img src="https://am23.akamaized.net/lc/cnt/uploads/2018/03/GettyImages-915103624.jpg" alt="" width="4632" height="3093" class="alignnone size-full wp-image-88324"></p>
<p>The <em>New York Times</em>&nbsp;apparently offers powerful third parties the ability to edit away&#8211;that is, to delete from the internet&#8211;unfavorable coverage appearing in the paper of record&#8217;s online edition.</p>
<p>One such entity afforded the privilege is Facebook.&nbsp;And this has legal experts raising antitrust concerns.</p>
<p>Last night, the <em>New York Times</em> broke <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/19/technology/facebook-alex-stamos.html">a very big story</a> regarding the pending departure of <strong>Alex Stamos</strong> from Facebook. Stamos is currently the company&#8217;s chief information security officer and the official largely responsible for tracking down the Russian troll farm influence and illicit campaign-related advertising facilitated through the Facebook platform. His duties have since been reassigned.</p>
<p>The <em>Times</em>&#8216; original story made reference to Facebook COO <strong>Sheryl Sandberg</strong>&#8211;and mentioned her &#8220;consternation&#8221; at Stamos&#8217; efforts to shepherd the tech giant towards being more transparent about Russian trolls&#8217; electoral interference. Here&#8217;s the original paragraph in question:</p>
<blockquote><p>Mr. Stamos had been a strong advocate inside the company for investigation and disclosing Russian activity on Facebook, often to the consternation of other top executives, including Sheryl Sandberg, the social network&#8217;s chief operating officer, according to the current and former employees, who asked not to be identified discussing internal matters.</p></blockquote>
<p>This morning, however, readers noticed the sole reference to Sandberg&#8217;s displeasure with Stamos&#8217; transparency efforts&#8211;viz. Russia in particular&#8211;was wiped clean off the ether. Now, Sandberg&#8217;s name and the story&#8217;s only reference to her alleged role in frustrating Stamos&#8217; attempts to highlight and root out Russian troll influence on the platform are gone because someone at the <em>New York Times</em> replaced the entire sentence.</p>
<p>Instead of an obvious reference to Facebook COO Sandberg, the <em>New York Times</em>&#8216; readership will note a vague reference to the fact that Stamos&#8217; anti-Russian transparency efforts were &#8220;met with resistance by colleagues.&#8221; There&#8217;s also no longer any explicit mention that Sandberg was one of those colleagues in the story. In other words, readers will now see nothing to suggest Sandberg had a problem with Stamos&#8217; work related to Russia.</p>
<p><strong>Justin Hendrix</strong> with the <a href="http://nycmedialab.org/">NYC Media Lab</a> noted the believed-to-be import of the since-altered sentence-graf in a tweet sent <a href="https://twitter.com/justinhendrix/status/975861225627234305">Monday at 3:27 p.m.</a> He wrote:</p>
<blockquote><p>Sheryl led the cover-up? &#8220;Mr. Stamos had been a strong advocate inside the company for investigating and disclosing Russian activity on Facebook, often to the consternation of other top executives, including Sheryl Sandberg&#8230;&#8221;</p></blockquote>
<p>A discussion regarding the decision soon began on Twitter after <strong>Kurt Walters</strong>, the campaign director for <a href="https://demandprogress.org">Demand Progress</a>, noted the deletion had occurred without a correction or clarification being issued by the <em>New York Times</em>.</p>
<p>Three reporters worked on the <em>New York Times</em> story regarding Stamos&#8217; eventual ouster: <strong>Nicole Perlroth</strong>, <strong>Sheera Frenkel</strong> and <strong>Scott Shane</strong>. Walters and <em>Law&amp;Crime</em> subsequently reached out to each reporter who worked on the story. Neither Frenkel nor Shane responded to repeat requests for comment.</p>
<p>Perlroth, however, confirmed that the change occurred after Facebook&#8217;s public relations team reached out to the <em>New York Times</em>&#8211;some time after the story was published.</p>
<p>In later comments, Perlroth downplayed the change, stating that the <em>New York Times</em> &#8220;regularly&#8221; engages in such practices. Perloth also defended the newer version of the article as substantially similar.</p>
<p><em>Law&amp;Crime</em>&nbsp;reached out to Facebook&#8217;s public relations firm for further comment and confirmation but no response was forthcoming at the time of publication.</p>
<p>To be clear, the <em>New York Times</em>&#8216; original reporting does not appear to be incorrect nor is there any indication this is the case. Indeed, Perlroth vehemently disagreed when asked if any of the Times&#8217; reporting was incorrect.</p>
<p>Additionally, other reputable outlets&#8211;like tech publication <em>Recode</em>&#8212;<a href="https://www.recode.net/2018/3/19/17141012/facebook-alex-stamos-departs-russia-fake-news">reported on the specificity of the Sandberg-Stamos disagreement</a>. <a href="https://qz.com/1232850/facebook-chief-security-officer-alex-stamos-is-reportedly-leaving-the-company/">Same goes for <em>Quartz</em></a>. <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-facebook-executives-stamos/facebooks-security-chief-to-depart-source-says-idUSKBN1GV2Z2">And <em>Reuters</em></a>.</p>
<p>Media watch dogs and corporate concentration experts immediately seized upon the glaring shift in coverage.</p>
<p><strong>Matt Stoller</strong>, a fellow at the <a href="https://openmarketsinstitute.org/">Open Markets Institute</a>&nbsp;who focuses on anti-trust and monopoly issues tweeted:</p>
<p><iframe id="twitter-widget-0" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" allowfullscreen="true" class="twitter-tweet twitter-tweet-rendered" data-tweet-id="976136770176905216" title="Twitter Tweet" style="position: static; visibility: visible; display: block; width: 500px; height: 231.171875px; padding: 0px; border: none; max-width: 100%; min-width: 220px; margin-top: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;"></iframe><script async="" src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script></p>
<p><strong>Jeff Hauser</strong>, Executive Director of the Revolving Door Project, at the <a href="http://cepr.net/about-us/staff/jeff-hauser-executive-director-of-the-revolving-door-project">Center for Economic and Policy Research</a>, is a noted anti-trust expert. In comments provided to&nbsp;<em>Law&amp;Crime,</em>&nbsp;Hauser explained the anti-trust and monopoly-like implications of Facebook&#8217;s muscling the <em>New York Times.&nbsp;</em>He said:</p>
<blockquote><p>[A]t the same time as Facebook and the <em>New York Time</em>s compete, Facebook is also an essential platform for the <em>New York Times</em> to reach readers, especially on phones. The <em>New York Times</em>&#8212; in fact, all advertising funded media &#8212; faces risks every time they report on Facebook in a way that reflects badly on Facebook. No company should be allowed to be as influential as Facebook while holding so much power over the media that a free society relies on to scrutinize powerful institutions. Facebook&#8217;s ability to flex its muscles over even the legendary <em>New York Times</em> should scare us about what they can do to smaller outlets contemplating negative coverage of Facebook practices.</p></blockquote>
<p>When asked as to whether current law could foreseeably deal with the potential trust-busting of a social media platform like Facebook, Hauser noted, &#8220;The likelihood that Facebook can intimidate the <em>New York Times</em> underscores the need to break up Facebook even if it is not charging advertisers or consumers provably &#8216;excessive&#8217; prices.&#8221;</p>
<p>Hauser cited to both the Sherman Antitrust Act and the Clayton Act as legal sources of authority that government and regulators could rely upon to hold tech giants more accountable&#8211;or even to break them up.</p>
<p>As for what that would take aside from statutory authority? Hauser said, &#8220;An executive branch dedicated to setting forth new interpretations of those statutes consistent with their explicit and historical meanings could initiate a new wave of &#8216;trust busting.&#8217; It&#8217;s a matter of newly restored will, not newly passed law.&#8221;</p>
